content:
• Wednesday, February 22, 2017
  • SM

    SM Energy EPS of -$2.20

    • SM Energy (NYSE:SM): Q4 EPS of -$2.20 may not be comparable to consensus of -$0.41.
    • Revenue of $379.9M (+25.1% Y/Y) beats by $12.22M.
    • Shares +1.3% AH.
    • Press Release
     
     
     
     
    | 10:05 PM | 1 Comment
  • TPCO

    Tronc revenues embrace ad decline though circulation rises

    • Tronc (TRNC +3.5%) posted revenues that missed expectations as advertising declined in Q4 earnings, though profits beat consensus.
    • Revenue by segment in troncM (media groups): Advertising, $187.6M (down 16%); Circulation, $126M (up 4.9%); Other, $53.8M (down 4%). In troncX (digital revenues): Advertising, $47.6M (down 3.3%); Content, $12.7M (up 21.2%).
    • EBITDA in troncX was $12.4M, down 3%, and in troncM, $64.2M, up 0.7%.
    • On a consolidated basis, ad revenues were down 13.7%, and circulation up 6% (with most growth coming to the Chicago Tribune, Los Angeles Times and Baltimore suburban papers).
    • Tronc noted that Timothy Knight has been named president of troncX effective tomorrow. He was co-founder of the business that created cars.com and apartments.com.
    • Shares are up 5.8% in late trading on thin volume.
    • Press Release
     
     
     
     
    | 6:48 PM
  • WB

    Weibo -2% despite above-consensus Q4 2016, revenue outlook

    • Q4 2016 results – revenue $212.7M (+42.7% Y/Y, $6.12M above estimates), EPS $0.34 ($0.06 above estimates), Advertising and marketing revenue $187.9M (+45% Y/Y), Weibo Value-Added Services revenue $24.9M (+28% Y/Y), net income attributable to Weibo $77M (+134% Y/Y), adjusted EBITDA $78.2M (+111% Y/Y)
    • Highlight metrics – MAUs in December 313M (+33% Y/Y), average DAUs in December 139M (+30% Y/Y)
    • Q1 2017 projections – revenue $185M-$190M (consensus $180.37M)
    • Weibo CEO Gaofei Wang: "Our growth in the fourth quarter was exceptional, with ad revenue from key accounts and SMEs doubling year over year. Weibo's user scale, breadth of ad offering and leadership as a social media platform in China put us in a unique position to take advantage of the marketing budget shift toward mobile, social and video. Our focus to grow scale in users, content creators, customers on our platform is translating into significant operating leverage."
    • After hours – (NASDAQ:WB) $57
    • Conference call / press release / Sina (NASDAQ:SINA) Q4 2016 report
     
     
     
     
    | 6:22 PM
  • TSLA

    Tesla earnings call: CFO exit, Model 3 production and Mars

    • Elon Musk opens the earnings call by stating that CFO Jason Wheeler plans to leave Tesla (NASDAQ:TSLA) to go into the public sector. Deepak Ahuja will return to the position he manned from August 2008 to November 2015.
    • On the key question of Model 3 production, Musk notes that the company has gained expertise in manufacturing and adds that the Model 3 is a "simpler" car to make than the S or X.
    • Musk brushes off a question about unionization at the Fremont plant, but delivers a strong answer to the threat of government EV subsidies being pulled back. He flips the script by suggesting that a lack of subsidies in the market could end up being a positive for Tesla.
    • There's no specific update on how many Model 3 reservations are on the books.
    • A question on Mars from a certain analyst from Morgan Stanley didn't add much to the mix.
    • Previously: Tesla outlines Model 3 timeline and Gigafactory growth (Feb. 22)
    • Tesla earnings call webcast
    • TSLA +2.33% AH to $279.89.
     
     
     
     
    | 6:13 PM | 102 Comments

  • INTC

    Nvidia -2.4% after hours, downgraded from Buy to Reduce at Instinet

    • Analyst Romit Shah considers overall view to be underappreciating a gaming slowdown and consequent prospective negative affect to multiple.
    • Suggests profit taking and a rotation into Buy-rated Intel (NASDAQ:INTC).
    • Nvidia (NASDAQ:NVDA) price target from $100 to $90 (current price $108.07).
     
     
     
     
    | 5:23 PM | 142 Comments
  • FIT

    Fitbit +0.34%; Q4 2016 results and outlook for Q1 off, FY 2017 forecasts roughly in line

    • Q4 2016 results – revenue $574M (-19.3% Y/Y, $2.04M below estimates), EPS -$0.56 ($0.06 below estimates), gross margin 22.4%, operating expenses 49.6% of revenue
    • Geographic revenues – U.S. -28%, EMEA +58%, APAC -56%, Other Americas -12%
    • Major product contribution – Fitbit Charge 2, Alta, Fitbit Blaze and Fitbit Flex 2 comprised 96% of revenue.
    • Q1 2017 projections – revenue $270M-$290M (consensus $307.46), EPS -$0.18 to -$0.20 (consensus -$0.15), tax rate 50%, stock-based compensation $23M-$25M
    • FY 2017 projections – revenue $1.5B-$1.7B (consensus $1.59B), EPS -$0.44 to -$0.22 (consensus -$0.32), gross margin 42.5%-44%, tax rate 50%, stock-based compensation expense $100M-$110M
    • Fitbit co-founder and CEO James Park: "Our ten-year history of building this category, coupled with our powerful brand and engaged global community gives us confidence we are making the right investments to support our vision and drive long-term success. We will leverage our leadership position, recently acquired talent and IP, and the valuable data we collect to improve demand and continue to set the pace of innovation for the industry through more personalized experiences, deeper insights and guidance, expansion into new categories and deeper integration within the healthcare system."
    • After hours – (NYSE:FIT) $5.90
    • Supplemental historical financial information / conference call / press release / presentation / 8-K
    • Previously (January 30, 2017): Fitbit -11.8%; Q4 2016 preliminary results, FY 2017 outlook significantly below expectations
     
     
     
     
    | 5:07 PM | 7 Comments

  • LB

    Weakness at Victoria's Secret impacts L Brands

    • L Brands (NYSE:LB) is down sharply after posting disappointing Q4 results and issuing some rattling guidance.
    • The company expects comparable sales to fall 20% at Victoria's Secret in February. A mid-to-high-teens decrease is expected across brands for the month. Further down the road, L Brands sees 2017 EPS falling in a range of $3.05 to $3.35.
    • Comparable sales were down 4% for VS in Q4, with the exit from swimsuit and some apparel categories a factor.
    • LB -12.02% AH to $51.25 (52-week low).
     
     
     
     
    | 4:57 PM | 41 Comments
  • NGD

    New Gold launches 53.6M-share bought deal financing

    • New Gold (NYSEMKT:NGD) -6.9% AH after announces a bought deal financing for 53.6M common shares at $2.80/share for ~$150M in gross proceeds, with an underwriters option to purchase up to an additional 8.04M shares.
    • NGD says it plans to use the proceeds to finance completion of the construction of the Rainy River gold project in Ontario.
     
     
     
     
    | 4:45 PM | 24 Comments
  • CAKE

    Comparable sales stay positive at Cheesecake Factory

    • Comparable restaurant sales increased 1.1% at Cheesecake Factory (NASDAQ:CAKE) in Q4. The mark isn't bad in comparison to the casual dining segment of the restaurant industry.
    • Labor expenses rose 80 bps to 33.6% of sales during the quarter.
    • Net income improved 20 bps to 5.4% of sales.
    • Previously: The Cheesecake Factory EPS in-line, beats on revenue (Feb. 22)
    • CAKE -1.50% AH to $59.20.

  • HPQ

    HP Q1 2017 over expectations, Q2 outlook midpoint below; +0.49%

    • Q1 2017 results – revenue $12.7B (+3.7% Y/Y, $850M above estimates), EPS $0.38 ($0.01 above estimates), net cash provided by operating activities $0.8B, repurchases and dividends $613M
    • Segments – Personal Systems (net revenue +10% Y/Y, commercial net revenue +7%, consumer net revenue +15%, total units +8%, notebook units +12%, desktops units unchanged), Printing (net revenue -3%, total hardware units +6%, commercial hardware units +2%, consumer hardware units +7%, supplies net revenue -3%)
    • Q2 projections – EPS $0.37-$0.40 (consensus $0.39)
    • HP president and CEO Dion Weisler: "In Q1, we delivered earnings at the high end of our outlook range with strong free cash flow, driven by relentless execution and innovation. We are confident in our ability to manage our business and deliver our FY17 financial commitments."
    • After hours – (NYSE:HPQ) $16.28
    • Conference call
    • Press release
    • 8-K
     
     
     
     
    | 4:29 PM | 2 Comments
  • ARRS

    Arris -7.3% as Q1 guidance comes up short, excluding Ruckus buy

    • Arris (NASDAQ:ARRS) has slipped 7.3% after hours following Q4 earnings that beat expectations but featured dim guidance for the first quarter.
    • The company's preliminary Q1 guidance is for sales of $1.44B-$1.49B (below consensus for $1.664B) for a GAAP loss of $0.13 to $0.09 (vs. consensus for a profit of $0.27) and for non-GAAP EPS of $0.36-$0.40 (below consensus for $0.67).
    • The company sees the rest of 2017 following trends similar to 2016. Guidance doesn't include a pending Ruckus Wireless purchase or that of the ICX Switch business. It's getting those from Brocade for $800M in cash, pending Broadcom's acquisition of Brocade.
    • In Q4, cash from operations was $40M. Order backlog was $1.106B, and the book-to-bill ratio was 1.04.
    • Conference call to come at 5 p.m. ET.
    • Press Release
     
     
     
     
    | 4:28 PM
  • TSLA

    Tesla outlines Model 3 timeline and Gigafactory growth

    • Tesla (NASDAQ:TSLA) says it's on track for Model 3 "initial production" in July, with volume production to follow in September.
    • The company expects to deliver between 47K and 50K Model S and Model X vehicles in the first half of this year.
    • On the autonomous front, Tesla says all vehicles in production have the hardware required for full-on self-driving
    • Q4 automotive margin was reported at 22.0% on a non-GAAP basis (ex-ZEV credit revenue) vs. 25.0% in Q3
    • Solar roof launches are expected in the back half of this year.
    • Gigafactory growth is also on tap. "Later this year, we expect to finalize locations for Gigafactories 3, 4 and possibly 5 (Gigafactory 2 is the Tesla solar plant in New York)," updates Tesla.
    • Capital spending will be a topic of the conference call (hopefully). Tesla says it invested $522M in manufacturing capacity for the Model 3, Gigafactory 1 and customer support infrastructure. "Our capital expenditures came in below plan as we continue to negotiate more favorable payment terms," notes the company.
    • Tesla shareholder letter (.pdf)
    • Previously: Tesla misses by $0.26, beats on revenue (Feb. 22)
    • Shares of Tesla are up 1.82% in AH trading to $278.47.
     
     
     
     
    | 4:24 PM | 174 Comments

  • FE

    FirstEnergy reiterates plan to sell or close its nuclear power plants

    • FirstEnergy (FE -1.7%) falls after missing estimates for both Q4 earnings and revenues, although it raised its FY 2017 EPS guidance above expectations to $2.70-$3.00, vs. $2.67 analyst consensus estimate.
    • FE says Q4 total distribution deliveries rose 4% Y/Y; weather-related usage resulted in an 8% rise in residential sales while commercial sales gained 3% due to a combination of weather and stronger demand.
    • FE made it clear during today's earnings conference call that it is leaving the competitive power plant business, closing or selling all of its plants, including its nuclear plants, by the middle of next year unless Ohio would consider re-regulating.
    • The company is proposing that Ohio create a program awarding "Zero Emission Credits" to its Davis-Besse and Perry power plants because the nuclear reactors do not produce carbon dioxide or other combustion pollutants.
     
     
     
     
    | 3:57 PM | 3 Comments
  • CHUY

    Investors cautious with restaurant stocks

    • The restaurant sector is having a rough day after Texas Roadhouse and Papa John's underwhelmed with their earnings reports.
    • Another consideration for investors could be the $1 drink promotion being fired off by McDonald's across the U.S. in April.
    • Notable decliners include Chuy's Holdings (CHUY -6.1%), Bloomin' Brands (BLMN -5.2%), Brinker International (EAT -4%), Ruth's Hospitality (RUTH -3.9%), Jack in the Box (JACK -3.5%), Del Taco (TACO -4%), Wendy's (WEN -3.4%), Domino's Pizza (DPZ -3.1%) and DineEquity (DIN -3.6%).
    • Cheesecake Factory (CAKE -1.1%) and Jack in the Box report earnings after the bell.
    • Previously: Texas Roadhouse peels back February gain after earnings (Feb. 22)
    • Previously: Papa John's slumps after revenue doesn't sizzle enough (Feb. 22)
    • Related ETF: BITE.
     
     
     
     
    | 3:42 PM | 3 Comments

    Cemtrex -37%; threatens legal action over misleading article

    • "Cemtrex (CETX -37.1%) categorically refutes any allegations of wrong-doing by the Company, its directors, officers and management," says the company, calling today's article from Seeking Alpha contributor Richard Pearson "fake news."
    • Cemtrex still plans its regularly scheduled conference call (dial-in) tomorrow at 11 ET.

  • NCLH

    Instinet sticks with positive view on Norwegian Cruise Line

    • Instinet analyst Harry Curtis weighs in on Norwegian Cruise Line Holdings (NCLH +7.4%) following the company's Q4 results.
    • "NCLH’s 2017 EPS outlook ($3.75 to $3.85) brackets our forecast ($3.75) and the Street’s ($3.79). However, we believe there could be upside to that range, given the positive booking and pricing trends so far this year. We remain positive on the shares of NCLH, which we believe should continue to outperform through 2017," writes Curtis.
    • Curtis has a Buy rating and $52 price target on the cruise line operator.
    • Previously: Norwegian Cruise Line Holdings beats by $0.01, beats on revenue (Feb. 22)
    • Previously: Norwegian Cruise Line Holdings positive post Q4 results (Feb. 22)
     
     
     
     
    | 2:56 PM | 1 Comment
  • HCLP

    Hi-Crush says frac sand pricing improving

    • Hi-Crush Partners (HCLP +4.7%) rallies as Q4 earnings fall just short of analyst estimates and revenue slips 6.6% Y/Y but still beat expectations, and frac sand volumes rise 25.5% to 1.36M tons.
    • HCLP says pricing improved in Q4, especially late in the quarter, and is continuing to accelerate in Q1, so it plans to operate its Wyeville, Blair and Augusta facilities near full capacity beginning as early as Q2, benefiting production costs and per-ton contribution margin; FSLR says it is also making preparations to restart the Whitehall production facility during Q2.
    • Frac sand peers also are higher: SLCA +2.6%, FMSA +2.7%, EMES +11.7%.
     
     
     
     
    | 2:56 PM | 8 Comments
  • KR

    Wal-Mart price cuts hit grocery names

    • Kroger (KR -2.9%) trades lower after Wolfe Research warns that price cuts enacted by Wal-Mart are impacting sales in the Midwest and Southeast.
    • Analyst Scott Mushkin thinks Target (TGT -0.7%) and Dollar General (DG -0.8%) could also feel the WMT effect.
    • Source: Bloomberg
     
     
     
     
    | 2:47 PM | 38 Comments
  • BHP

    BHP eyes 30-day wait to replace workers in Escondida strike

    • BHP Billiton's (BHP -2.5%) surprise decision this week to give up its legal right to replace striking workers at the Escondida copper mine in Chile is a move aimed at sacrificing some production to undermine the union's position, analysts tell Reuters.
    • BH says its announcement not to exercise its right to replace the 2,500 striking workers after 15 days - which would have been this Friday - and instead wait at least 30 days was to ensure the safety of its workers, but industry experts say it was a strategic move, since workers after 30 days can individually exit the strike and accept the company's offer, weakening the union's position.
     
     
     
     
    | 2:31 PM

  • Dollar down, gold higher following FOMC minutes

    • The FOMC minutes seemingly confirm that a March rate hike is very much in play (even as markets price the chance at just about one-in-three), but the dollar (UUP, UDN) is giving back some ground as participants expressed concern about the greenback's appreciation (it's essentially flat over the last two years), and gold (GLD +0.2%) is on a modest rise in the immediate aftermath of the news.
    • In fixed-income, bonds are adding to small gains (TLT +0.2%), with the 10-year yield now lower by 1.3 basis points to 2.417%.
    • Stocks have turned a hair lower, with the S&P 500 (NYSEARCA:SPY) down 0.15%.
     
     
     
     
    | 2:15 PM | 24 Comments

    • Net investment income of $3.5M up 96.1%. Total invested assets of $651.6M vs. $489.4M a year ago.

  • HST

    Host Hotels -2.45%, can't hold post-earnings gains

    • The company reported Q4 adjusted FFO per share of $0.41, up from $0.39 one year ago, and ahead of estimates by $0.04. Full-year AFFO per share of $1.69 vs. $1.54 earned in 2015.
    • Q4 comparable hotel EBITDA up 4.3%; comparable RevPAR on a constant dollar basis up 1.7%, with a 0.6% increase in average room rate and 80 basis point gain in occupancy.
    • 700K shares bought back during quarter at average price of $15.82 each; full year buybacks of 13.8M shares for $15.79 each. New buyback program of up to $500M is authorized.
    • Full-year AFFO per share is guided to $1.60-$1.70 vs. $1.69 earned in 2016. Consensus is for $1.65.
    • Previously: Host Hotels & Resorts beats by $0.04, beats on revenue (Feb. 22)

  • WELL

    Modest gain for Welltower after Q4 earnings beat

    • Full-year normalized FFO per share of $4.55 vs. $4.38 in 2015.
    • Q4 normalized FAD per share of $0.99 flat from one year ago. Full-year FAD per share of $4.08 vs. $3.85 in 2015. Quarterly dividend of $0.87, up from $0.86 the previous quarter.
    • Total portfolio same-store NOI growth of 2.3% in Q4. Same-store seniors housing operating REVPOR growth of 4.3%. Private pay revenue mix up to 92.8%.
    • Full-year normalized FFO per share guidance of $4.15-$4.25, with same-store NOI growth of 2-3%.
    • Previously: Welltower beats by $0.01, beats on revenue (Feb. 22)

  • FSLR

    First Solar "the one to own" in a challenging environment, Baird says

    • First Solar (FSLR -6.8%) is defended at Baird after shares sink nearly 7% on a disappointing solar outlook, saying the stock is "the one to own" if investors want exposure to the solar market.
    • FSLR lowered its gross margin guidance to 11%-13% from a previous 12.5%-14.5%, and the firm acknowledges that the solar market outlook remains challenging but FSLR's pipeline, technology and balance sheet "should allow it to remain a market leader."
    • Baird notes FSLR's top-line and bottom-line Q4 beat and the fact that the company's products are commanding a premium price in select markets, and that FSLR already booked ~0.5 GW worth of projects YTD and has ~2.2 GW of mid- to late-stage opportunities ahead, which boosts confidence that the company is well positioned to record bookings throughout the year.
     
     
     
     
    | 12:33 PM | 30 Comments

  • Euro gains on French alliance against Le Pen, Fillon

    • Independent candidate Emmanuel Macron and centrist rival Francois Bayrou have agreed to join, thus boosting Macron's chances of a 2nd place finish (over Republican Francois Fillon) in the first election round on April 23.
    • Nationalist Marine Le Pen currently leads in the polls, but it's assumed that whoever finishes 2nd will win the run-off on May 7 as currently split voters align against Le Pen.
    • The euro (NYSEARCA:FXE) has gained about 60 pips since Macron's announcement, now higher by 0.3% on the session at $1.0560.
    • The iShares MSCI France Index (EWQ +0.1%)
    • ETFs: FXE, EUO, ERO, DRR, ULE, EUFX, URR
     
     
     
     
    | 12:19 PM | 9 Comments

  • WLL

    Whiting Petroleum -5% after nearly doubling 2017 capex plan

    • Whiting Petroleum (WLL -5.4%) sinks after posting a smaller than expected Q4 loss but nearly doubling its 2017 capital spending budget to $1.1B from $554M in 2016.
    • Also, WLL's Q4 revenue fell 18% Y/Y as production fell 23.4% to 118.9K boe/day, above the high end of company guidance of 117.4K boe/day and better than Q3 but below Wall Street expectations.

    Aethlon's Hemopurifier shows ability to remove viral pathogens from blood samples; shares ahead 3%

    • Researchers at Aethlon Medical (AEMD +3.4%) have demonstrated the ability of the Hemopurifier device to remove viral pathogens from blood samples obtained from organ transplant patients who were suffering from sepsis.
    • Results showed that the Hemopurifier was able to reduce the level of Herpes Simplex virus 1 (HSV1) by 72% after six hours. Levels of Epstein-Barr virus (EBV) and Cytomegalovirus (CMV) were reduced 77% and 88%, respectively.
    • Hemopurifier is a bio-filtration device designed to remove bioterror-related pathogens. Studies have also shown its ability to remove the Zika virus from serum.

  • ARGSQ

    Late-stage study unlikely to show treatment benefit of Argos Therapeutics' lead product candidate; shares plummet 65% premarket

    • Thinly traded micro cap Argos Therapeutics (ARGS) craters 65% premarket on robust volume in response to its announcement that its Phase 3 clinical trial, ADAPT, assessing lead product candidate rocapuldencel-T, in combination with Pfizer's SUTENT (sunitinib malate), for the treatment of metastatic renal cell carcinoma (kidney cancer) will probably fail.
    • An interim data analysis by the independent Data Monitoring Committee showed that the study will be unlikely to demonstrate a statistically valid improvement in overall survival in the combination treatment arm, the primary endpoint. The DMC has recommended the study be discontinued for futility.
    • The company says it will analyze the data itself and will discuss the results with the FDA prior to deciding on what action to take with the rocapuldencel-T program.
    • Rocapuldencel-T is an individualized immunotherapy that captures both mutated and variant antigens that are unique to each patient's tumor. It is specifically designed to induce an immune response targeting the patient's particular tumor antigens.
     
     
     
     
    | 8:58 AM | 9 Comments

  • AGEN

    Agenus shuts down mid-stage study of Prophage G-200 due to lack of treatment effect; shares ease 5% premarket

    • In a regulatory fling released today, Agenus (NASDAQ:AGEN) reports that has stopped patient accrual in its Phase 2 clinical trial assessing Prophage G-200 [Heat Shock Protein Peptide Complex-96 (HSPPC-96)], in combination with Roche's Avastin (bevacizumab), in patients with surgically resectable recurrent glioblastoma multiforme (GBM) (brain tumor).
    • Recruitment was stopped after an interim analysis by the Data Safety and Monitoring Board showed the study was unlikely to demonstrate a treatment benefit over bevacizumab alone.
    • A study assessing the combination of HSPPC-96 and Merck's Keytruda (pembrolizumab) in GBM is about to start.
    • Prophage is an individualized autologous vaccine candidate derived from the patient's tumor. It is designed to "educate" the immune system to recognize the tumor as foreign and elicit an anti-tumor response.
    • Shares are down 5% premarket on light volume.
